message.content:
This poem speaks to the child-like innocence, wonder, and love for nature that often inhabits a person during their youth. The speaker is reminiscing about joyful times exploring and playing in the natural world. 

The first lines of the poem introduce us immediately to this atmosphere of joyous play, as we see children running through beautiful unspoiled landscapes, such as meadows full of flowers or forests filled with bird songs. Their laughter rings out like music all around them: "For beauty easily beguiles/Poixen-hearts with tender trade." Nature's allure has captured their hearts and made them content.

Various specific attributes of nature are mentioned throughout the poem - beautiful vistas drenched in sunlight ("What golden hours did then unfold"), enchanting creatures who reside there (like gryphons), weather phenomena (thunderstorms) that evoke both fear and fascination. Nature is presented as an endless source for adventure and mystery.

As time passes by, these memories turn into "pearl-sweet days," cherished moments from childhood when everything seemed magical; they can now only dwell within one's heart: "Why fade these visions from my way?" With age comes responsibility and seriousness that often leave little room for heartfelt appreciation or deeper connections to the natural world around us: adults cannot enter directly into such a realm anymore since our perspective changes over time leaving behind innocence regarded fondly here.

But even later in life where experiences take precedence over youthful impressions some aspect remains alive capable creating various emotions depending on circumstances overall impact past had psyche thus ensuring those experiences won't ever completely disappear reach willingness connect continue embody spirit faith active effort towards attaining happiness will beneficial aspects shown bridge starting point future endeavors maintaining positive attitude abundance lessons available everyone regardless age teach wisdom humility
